messages.text: Denmark seem to be completely losing control of the situation. More restrictions were added earlier in December, but the numbers kept rising nevertheless. We now have nearly twice the number of hospitalized as we did at the spring peak, and the Christmas infections hasn't even hit yet. We are about to have the new year's evening parties, which are traditionally drunk and disinhibited, and this with a population already weary of the restrictions. New restrictions will be announced by the prime minister in one hour. Unless restrictions are truly draconian, I expect the situation to completely derail the next two weeks.

elements.text: Denmark seem to be completely losing control of the situation. More restrictions were added earlier in December, but the numbers kept rising nevertheless. We now have nearly twice the number of hospitalized as we did at the spring peak, and the Christmas infections hasn't even hit yet. We are about to have the new year's evening parties, which are traditionally drunk and disinhibited, and this with a population already weary of the restrictions. New restrictions will be announced by the prime minister in one hour. Unless restrictions are truly draconian, I expect the situation to completely derail the next two weeks.

messages.text:
The papers in the UK are talking about a Tier 5.
Even though their is actually no real source on it just some advisor to an advisor to the government saying they thought there needed to be a new level of restrictions.

We had tier 1-3 of restrictions; where still things were open, but e.g. hospitality was increasingly restricted, and number of people you were allowed to meet went down.
then Tier 4 was recently added that was basically the same as the 2nd lockdown rules: stay home, everything non-essential is closed, schools are open, unlimited exercise permitted. Plus strong recommendation for vulnerable people to say at home at all times (which we hadn‚Äôt had since first lockdown)
I guess a tier 5 would look a bit more like first lockdown.
Schools closed, excise restricted to 1 session of ‚Äúreasonable length‚Äù, need a good reason to leave your house.

Idk it is hard to see how they can esculate.  Possibly if they do bring in needing a good reason to leave the house then they can bring in enformence of that. Though that didn‚Äôt go down well before.

messages.text: It seems like we are past a limit beyond which a large part of society will not attend the government call. Maybe 9 months was that limit. Mexico City keeps opening new hospitals, adding campaign hospitals, adding beds in the parking lots of hospitals, bringing doctors from other states, but numbers keep rising from gatherings, travel, etc‚Ä¶ There is just no way to add that many beds.

attachments.title: Mexico Misled Citizens About the Severity of Coronavirus in its Capital
attachments.text: The federal government had data that should have prompted an immediate lockdown in early December. Instead, it kept the city open for another two weeks.

messages.text: That note has been disputed by the government. To be fair this is one of the most transparent and progressive governments we have had in many years, so I remain skeptical of that note even if it is by the NYT. The federal government answers questions from journalists every day and the local one at least once a week, but I have never seen that journalist come to ask questions directly from the people handling the pandemic. The public health system is enormous but it had been abandoned for decades (one of the two main social security institutions had not opened a new hospital in around 20 years and it just did). Fortunately the federal government had been investing in the system the last two years, and I think one of the few things the pandemic will leave is that it is really forcing an even larger investment in our old, long forgotten system.

elements.text: That note has been disputed by the government. The public health system is enormous but it had been abandoned for decades (one of the two main social security institutions had not opened a new hospital in around 20 years and it just did). Fortunately the federal government had been investing in the system the last two years, and I think one of the few things the pandemic will leave is that it is really forcing an even larger investment in our old, long forgotten system.

messages.text: I‚Äôm currently stuck sharing a house with somebody who 1) teaches 3-12 year olds 5 days a week in person 2) goes shopping a few times a week 3) is out with other people Friday night, as well as most of Saturday and Sunday.   I‚Äôm really tired now of having to take social distancing precautions *inside* the house (I am at high risk if I get COVID-19, due to age, high blood pressure and Type 2 diabetes).   Now with this new strain, that makes it even more likely that I‚Äôll catch it right here at home, really makes me feel hopeless.

messages.text: I'm quite worried about the increased posting here of articles from "international news" that are pretty much opinion pieces describing the situation and the response made in different countries. This articles often have a conspiracy type of angle and are likely optimized to drive clicks / provide ad revenue by praying on peoples fear and schadenfreude. I think it would be good to try keep posting towards more factual type of articles instead.

messages.text:
I am feeling fairly hopeful about the UK's ability to hit 2 million vaccinations/week by end of January.

The 1million in the last month was with about 1 vaccination site for every 6 GP practices.
With the Oxford vaccine because it's so easy to deal with, being it only needs normal fridge and there is no need to observe people for 15minutes after it's going to be much better.
They say they are planning for every GP practice.
Plus pharmacists.
Plus mass vaccination centers (which are due to open 2nd week of January)

According to the defense secretary (so take it with more than a few grains of salt) they have 250 trained teams of military personnel who estimate they can do 100,000 vaccinations per day.

And while I am reading that volunteers are hella frustrated with how hard it is to get certified to be allowed to volunteer, they still have recruited thousands of people.

So while I think it will be a pretty shaky first few weeks, I am hopeful.

elements.text:
I am feeling fairly hopeful about the UK's ability to hit 2 million vaccinations/week by end of January.

The 1million in the last month was with about 1 vaccination site for every 6 GP practices.
With the Oxford vaccine because it's so easy to deal with, being it only needs normal fridge and there is no need to observe people for 15minutes after it's going to be much better.
They say they are planning for every GP practice.
Plus pharmacists.
Plus mass vaccination centers (which are due to open 2nd week of January)

According to the defense secretary (so take it with more than a few grains of salt) they have 250 trained teams of military personnel who estimate they can do 100,000 vaccinations per day.

And while I am reading that volunteers are hella frustrated with how hard it is to get certified to be allowed to volunteer, they still have recruited thousands of people.

So while I think it will be a pretty shaky first few weeks, I am hopeful.

messages.text: I just googled 'covid finland sauna' and it led to <https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7372531/>. I can imagine that a dark covid winter in Finland isn't necessarily so bad

attachments.title: Turning up the heat on COVID-19: heat as a therapeutic intervention
attachments.text: Enveloped viruses such as SAR-CoV-2 are sensitive to heat and are destroyed by temperatures tolerable to humans. All mammals use fever to deal with infections and heat has been used throughout human history in the form of hot springs, saunas, hammams, ...
attachments.fallback: PubMed Central (PMC): Turning up the heat on COVID-19: heat as a therapeutic intervention

attachments.title: Assessing the age specificity of infection fatality rates for COVID-19: systematic review, meta-analysis, and public policy implications
attachments.text: Determine age-specific infection fatality rates for COVID-19 to inform public health policies and communications that help protect vulnerable age groups. Studies of COVID-19 prevalence were collected by conducting an online search of published articles, preprints, and government reports that were publicly disseminated prior to 18 September 2020. The systematic review encompassed 113 studies, of which 27 studies (covering 34 geographical locations) satisfied the inclusion criteria and were included in the meta-analysis. Age-specific IFRs were computed using the prevalence data in conjunction with reported fatalities 4 weeks after the midpoint date of the study, reflecting typical lags in fatalities and reporting. Meta-regression procedures in Stata were used to analyze the infection fatality rate (IFR) by age. Our analysis finds a exponential relationship between age and IFR for COVID-19. The estimated age-specific IFR is very low for children and younger adults (e.g., 0.002% at age 10 and 0.01% at age 25) but increases progressively to 0.4% at age 55, 1.4% at age 65, 4.6% at age 75, and 15% at age 85. Moreover, our results indicate that about 90% of the variation in population IFR across geographical locations reflects differences in the age composition of the population and the extent to which relatively vulnerable age groups were exposed to the virus. These results indicate that COVID-19 is hazardous not only for the elderly but also for middle-aged adults, for whom the infection fatality rate is two orders of magnitude greater than the annualized risk of a fatal automobile accident and far more dangerous than seasonal influenza. Moreover, the overall IFR for COVID-19 should not be viewed as a fixed parameter but as intrinsically linked to the age-specific pattern of infections. Consequently, public health measures to mitigate infections in older adults could substantially decrease total deaths.
attachments.fallback: European Journal of Epidemiology: Assessing the age specificity of infection fatality rates for COVID-19: systematic review, meta-analysis, and public policy implications

attachments.title: Immunological memory to SARS-CoV-2 assessed for up to 8 months after infection
attachments.text: Understanding immune memory to SARS-CoV-2 is critical for improving diagnostics and vaccines, and for assessing the likely future course of the COVID-19 pandemic. We analyzed multiple compartments of circulating immune memory to SARS-CoV-2 in 254 samples from 188 COVID-19 cases, including 43 samples at ‚â• 6 months post-infection. IgG to the Spike protein was relatively stable over 6+ months. Spike-specific memory B cells were more abundant at 6 months than at 1 month post symptom onset. SARS-CoV-2-specific CD4+ T cells and CD8+ T cells declined with a half-life of 3-5 months. By studying antibody, memory B cell, CD4+ T cell, and CD8+ T cell memory to SARS-CoV-2 in an integrated manner, we observed that each component of SARS-CoV-2 immune memory exhibited distinct kinetics.
attachments.fallback: Science: Immunological memory to SARS-CoV-2 assessed for up to 8 months after infection

messages.text: These studies and others31012 offer strong evidence that T cell immune responses are sustained, even in the face of declining or undetectable antibodies, implying that some immunity persists. It is possible, but as yet unconfirmed, that immunity might last even longer, as T cell responses to SARS-CoV-1 and MERS-CoV have been found several years after infection.13 The evidence from new studies, interim results from phase III vaccine trials, and previous data from phase I and phase II trials support the notion that memory T cell responses to the vaccines, along with B cell antibody responses, should provide good and possibly enduring immunity to SARS-Cov-2. This, together with continuing public health measures, should help lay a pathway out of the pandemic.

elements.text: These studies and others31012 offer strong evidence that T cell immune responses are sustained, even in the face of declining or undetectable antibodies, implying that some immunity persists. It is possible, but as yet unconfirmed, that immunity might last even longer, as T cell responses to SARS-CoV-1 and MERS-CoV have been found several years after infection.13 The evidence from new studies, interim results from phase III vaccine trials, and previous data from phase I and phase II trials support the notion that memory T cell responses to the vaccines, along with B cell antibody responses, should provide good and possibly enduring immunity to SARS-Cov-2. This, together with continuing public health measures, should help lay a pathway out of the pandemic.

messages.text: From : <https://www.bmj.com/content/371/bmj.m4838|https://www.bmj.com/content/371/bmj.m4838>

attachments.title: Covid-19 vaccines: delivering protective immunity
attachments.text: Evidence supports both T and B cell responses to the three leading vaccines Early in the covid-19 pandemic it was unclear whether and how individuals and populations would develop protective and enduring immunity against SARS-CoV-2, either after infection or vaccination. Initial focus was on defining virus neutralising antibodies from B cells after infection. Early reports indicated that such antibodies decline substantially over less than six months, raising questions about how long protective immunity might last following infection. T cells are also known to be important in protecting against many viral infections through processes known as cellular immunity. Defining the roles of T cells in covid-19 became a central focus for investigation.1 Both memory T cell and B cell responses specific to SARS-CoV-223 have now been found up to six months after infection. Similar T and B cell responses might be expected following vaccination, and may account for the good efficacy suggested by interim results from the three most advanced vaccine candidates.456 All three vaccines‚Äîtwo mRNA vaccines (Pfizer-BioNTech and ‚Ä¶
attachments.fallback: The BMJ: Covid-19 vaccines: delivering protective immunity

Also the security guard moonlights as a Uber driver :disappointed: 
I thought WA would be not letting people working in covid facilities have other jobs.

This may again spark calls for quarentine to be moved out of inner city hotels and into some remote facility.

messages.text:
Are UK vacations per day periodic?
I can imagine a peak on certain days like e.g. a bunch of GPs were opening up on Saturday solely for vaccinations only.
And a ton being closed entirely on Sunday

But not that it seems the peak is followed by a trough and slowly builds back up.

Are they running out of vaccines, then not sure when they will get more and so don't pre-book patients?
And then patients need a few days notice to get in?

attachments.text: Analyses reveal single standard dose efficacy from day 22 to day 90 post vaccination of 76% with protection not falling in this three-month periodAfter the second dose vaccine efficacy from two standard doses is 82.4% with the 3-month interval being used in the UK. (82.4% effective, with a 95% confidence interval of 62.7% - 91.7% at 12+ weeks)Data supports the 4-12 week prime-boost dosing interval recommended by many global regulatorsAnalyses of PCR positive swabs in UK population suggests vaccine may have substantial effect on transmission of the virus with 67% reduction in positive swabs among those vaccinated

messages.text: An acquaintance of mine heard something about some of the new variants being more virulent in kids, but I can't find any sources. It seems a bit implausible to me, but I wanted to try to track down where that idea came from before saying more about it

attachments.title: Russia tells WHO it has detected first case of avian flu strain in humans
attachments.text: Russian authorities say they have detected what is believed to be "human infection with avian influenza H5N8," the World Health Organization (WHO) has confirmed to CNN.
attachments.fallback: CNN: Russia tells WHO it has detected first case of avian flu strain in humans

attachments.title: First vaccine to fully immunize against malaria builds on pandemic-driven RNA tech
attachments.text: Consistently ranked as one of the leading causes of death around the world, malaria doesn‚Äôt have an effective vaccine yet. But researchers have invented a promising new blueprint for one ‚Äî with properties akin to the novel RNA-based vaccine for COVID-19.
